description: A rich, creamy, and flavorful stew made from garden eggs (African eggplants) simmered in a savory groundnut (peanut) sauce. It has a unique, slightly bitter undertone balanced by the nutty, creamy sauce, creating a deeply comforting and nutritious dish.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Garden Eggs Entula is a classic dish, especially in regions where garden eggs are widely cultivated. It is a staple in many households, valued for its ability to create a satisfying, protein-rich meal without meat. The process of boiling and mashing the garden eggs into a creamy base is a traditional technique that gives the stew its distinctive texture and helps thicken the groundnut sauce.

ingredients.name: Smoked Fish or Meat (Optional)
ingredients.notes: Flaked or diced, for added protein

steps.instruction: Place the whole garden eggs and the roughly chopped onion in a large pot. Cover with water and boil for 15-20 minutes until the garden eggs are very tender and can be easily pierced with a fork.
Drain the garden eggs, reserving about 2 cups of the boiling water. Let the garden eggs cool slightly, then peel off the skins (they should come off easily).
Return the peeled garden eggs to the pot. Use a masher or wooden spoon to mash them into a rough, chunky paste.
In a separate bowl, mix the groundnut paste with 1-2 cups of the reserved boiling water (or fresh water) until you have a smooth, creamy, pourable consistency.
In a clean large pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until soft and golden.
Add the tomato paste and curry powder. Stir and cook for 1 minute.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for 3-4 minutes until they break down.
Pour the groundnut sauce into the pot. Add the mashed garden eggs, the remaining salt, and the whole chili pepper. Stir well to combine. If using smoked fish or meat, add it now.

Bring the stew to a simmer, then reduce the heat to low. Cover and let it cook for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking, until the stew has thickened and the oil starts to surface.

cooking_indicators.visual: The stew will thicken, darken in color, and oil will glisten on the surface.

steps.instruction: Adjust salt to taste. Remove the whole chili pepper if desired. Stir in fresh cilantro just before serving.
Serve the Garden Eggs Entula hot in a bowl.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served with Matoke (steamed green bananas), Posho (Ugali), or Cassava. It can also be eaten with Rice or Chapati.
